meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Lovett-Barron, UCSD
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hey, everybody, I'm Matt. I'm a postdoc in the Voytek lab. I'm really interested in the intersection of behavior and computation. I think that's a really interesting place to be right now. I'm really interested in how we can use computation to better understand behavior and how we can use behavior to better understand computation. I think there's a lot of really interesting questions to be asked there. I'm really excited to be here and to learn from all of you.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Melike Lakadamyali, UPenn
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi everyone, I'm Melike. I'm a professor at UPenn. My lab works on super resolution microscopy and we apply it to study the organization and function of proteins in cells. So we're interested in how proteins are organized in cells and how that organization affects their function. And we're also interested in how that organization is regulated by different signaling pathways. So we use super resolution microscopy to visualize proteins at the nanoscale and then we use computational methods to analyze the data and extract information about protein organization and function. And we're also interested in developing new super resolution microscopy methods that can be used to study proteins in living cells.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Arnold Hayer, McGill
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, I'm Arnold Hayer. I'm at McGill University in Montreal. I'm interested in cell migration and how cells sense their environment and how they integrate that information to make decisions about where to go. And I'm also interested in how cells interact with each other and how they coordinate their movements. So I'm really interested in how cells make decisions and how they coordinate their movements.
